questions.text: Which of the following is not an emergency contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Danazol

Explanation:

Emergency contraception, also known as post-coital contraception or the "morning-after pill," is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure.

Danazol is not used for emergency contraception. It is a medication primarily indicated for the treatment of endometriosis and certain hormone-related conditions. It does not prevent pregnancy.

CuT200 (Option B) refers to a copper intrauterine device (IUD) that can be used as emergency contraception. When inserted within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse, the copper IUD can prevent pregnancy. It is an effective and long-acting form of emergency contraception.

RU486 (Option C), also known as mifepristone or the "abortion pill," is not a method used for post-coital contraception. It is a medication used for medical abortion or termination of an established pregnancy. It works by blocking the action of progesterone, which is necessary to maintain pregnancy.

Combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills (Option D) have been used as emergency contraception in the past but are no longer recommended due to their potential side effects. They are less effective and have more significant adverse effects compared to other available emergency contraception options, such as dedicated emergency contraceptive pills or the copper IUD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to subcutaneous contraceptive implant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Undiagnosed genital bleeding

Explanation:

  • Undiagnosed genital bleeding can be a sign of serious underlying conditions like endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, or structural lesions.
  • Inserting a subcutaneous contraceptive implant without first diagnosing the cause could delay detection and treatment of a potentially dangerous condition.
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria lists it as Category 4 (unacceptable health risk) until the cause is clarified.

Incorrect Options:

Hypertension (Option A): Most progestin-only contraceptives (like implants) do not significantly raise blood pressure. It is safe in most women with controlled hypertension (Category 1–2), though regular monitoring is advised.

Diabetes mellitus (Option B): Progestin-only implants have minimal metabolic impact and are generally safe for diabetic patients, unless there is severe vascular disease.

PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) (Option C): Implants act systemically, not via the intrauterine route, so they don’t worsen PID risk. The main concern with PID is for intrauterine devices (IUDs), not implants.

questions.text: OCPs can be given in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HIV

Explanation:

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are generally contraindicated in certain high-risk conditions due to their estrogen component, which can increase the risk of thromboembolic and cardiovascular events.

  • In HIV, OCPs can still be used safely, though drug interactions with some antiretroviral drugs may occur, but HIV itself is not a contraindication.

Complications associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Complication

Details

Minor Complications

Nausea, Vomiting, Headache

Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolves over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent.

Mastalgia

Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles.

Weight Gain

Minimal long-term weight gain

Menstrual Abnormalities

Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use.

Libido

Changes in sexual desire can occur

Leukorrhea

Increase in vaginal discharge

Major Complications

Depression

Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations

Hypertension

Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment.

Vascular Complications
  • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking. (Option A)
 
  • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction

Cholestatic Jaundice

Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs.

Neoplasia

Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

Incorrect Options:

HTN (Option A): Moderate to severe uncontrolled hypertension is a contraindication to combined OCPs due to increased cardiovascular risk.

DM (Option B): In diabetics with vascular complications or >20 years duration of disease, OCPs are contraindicated due to the risk of worsening microvascular disease.

Hyperlipidemia (Option D): Uncontrolled hyperlipidemia is a contraindication as estrogen can further raise triglyceride levels and cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes for emergency contraception within 8 hours after engaging in sexual intercourse. She expresses a preference for a single pill rather than multiple pills. What would be your recommendation in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

Explanation:

  • Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the most appropriate option for emergency contraception in this case. It is a progestin-only pill and is highly effective when taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. Since the patient prefers a single-pill regimen, this option is ideal. It does not contain estrogen, avoiding estrogen-related side effects such as nausea or vomiting.

Emergency Contraceptive Methods

Method

Drug(s)

Dosage

Schedule

Time Period for Use

Oral Contraceptive Pills

Levonorgestrel

1.5 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Combination Pills (Yuzpe Regimen)

Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl estradiol

Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg + Ethinyl estradiol 0.1 mg per tablet

2 doses, 12 hours apart

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Levonorgestrel

Levonorgestrel

0.75 mg per tablet (take 2 tablets)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Ulipristal Acetate

Ulipristal acetate

30 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex

Copper IUD (Best)

Copper IUD

N/A (inserted by healthcare provider)

Insertion by a healthcare provider

Within 5 days after unprotected sex

Mifepristone (Less Common)

Mifepristone (in combination with misoprostol)

200 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Incorrect Options:

While levonorgestrel 0.75 mg (Option A) is used in some regimens, it requires two doses (one pill initially and another 12 hours later). Since the patient prefers a single pill, this option is not suitable.

Ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel (Option B) combination contains both estrogen (ethinyl estradiol) and progestin (levonorgestrel). While effective, the estrogen component increases the risk of side effects, including nausea and vomiting, which the patient is trying to avoid.

Desogestrel 3 mg (Option D) is a progestin-only contraceptive, but it is not typically used for emergency contraception. Furthermore, it is often combined with estrogen, which would introduce unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: Oral contraceptive pill prevents all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cervical cancer

Explanation:

  • OCPs have documented protective effects against epithelial ovarian cancer and endometrial cancer by suppressing ovulation and providing a progestin-dominant environment.
  • Some studies also suggest a modest protective effect against colorectal cancer.
  • However, long-term OCP use is associated with a slightly increased risk of cervical cancer due to hormonal influence on HPV persistence.

OCP cancer protection profile:

  1. Protective against: Epithelial ovarian, endometrial, and possibly colorectal cancer.
  2. No protection / Slightly increased risk: Cervical and breast cancer (with prolonged use).
  3. Mechanism: Reduced ovulation, decreased endometrial proliferation, hormonal modulation of certain tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Epithelial ovarian cancer (Option B): Protected — OCP suppresses ovulation, reducing repeated ovarian epithelial trauma, lowering cancer risk.

Endometrial cancer (Option C): Protected — Progestin in OCP counteracts estrogen’s proliferative effect on endometrium, reducing malignancy risk.

Colon cancer (Option D): Protected (modest) — Possibly via hormonal modulation; mechanism not fully established but supported by some epidemiologic data.

questions.text:
What are the correct timings for intrauterine device (IUD) insertion?


	Immediate postpartum
	Up to 48 hours postpartum
	Within 5-7 days of the menstrual cycle
	5-7 days before the next menstrual cycle
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A, B, C

Explanation:

Inserting an Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) 5–7 days before the next menstrual cycle is not a standard or recommended practice, as it carries a higher risk of undetected pregnancy at the time of insertion.

  • They are small, T-shaped devices used for long-acting reversible contraception. They work through several mechanisms:
    • Prevention of Sperm Motility and Viability: IUCDs induce a local inflammatory response in the uterus, producing leukocytes and prostaglandins that hinder sperm motility and viability.
    • Alteration of Cervical Mucus: Hormonal IUCDs release progestin, which thickens cervical mucus, obstructing sperm entry into the uterus.
    • Inhibition of Ovulation: In hormonal IUCDs, progestin may suppress ovulation in some women, providing additional contraceptive effects.
    • Prevention of Implantation: IUCDs modify the endometrial lining, making it less conducive to implantation, though this is a secondary mechanism.

 

Timing of IUD insertion

Ideal time
  • During menstruation or within the first 10 days of the start of period (Point C)

Preferred time
  • Postpartum (immediate postpartum): Post-placenta insertion; Has a higher rate of expulsion (Point A)
  • Late postpartum: Within 48 hours of delivery or up to 1 week (Point B)

Other times
  • Post-puerperal: After 6-8 weeks of delivery
  • Post-coital: Up to 3-5 days after unprotected intercourse.
  • Post-abortion: After 1st trimester loss.
    • Not recommended after a 2nd trimester abortion.

questions.text: Contraindications of the device shown in image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease):

  • Let's discuss the contraindications associated with the device shown in the image, which is a Copper T intrauterine device (IUD).
  • PID is a contraindication for Copper T IUD use. If a woman has an active pelvic inflammatory disease, inserting an IUD could increase the risk of complications and should be avoided.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Breastfeeding: Breastfeeding is not a contraindication for Copper T IUD use. In fact, Copper T IUDs are often considered suitable for breastfeeding women.

Option B - Monogamous: Monogamy or the number of sexual partners is not a specific contraindication for Copper T IUD use.

Option C - Hypertension: Hypertension is not a contraindication for Copper T IUD use. However, healthcare providers may consider other factors such as cardiovascular health in the overall assessment.

questions.text: The Pearl index is used to calculate which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Accidental pregnancies

Explanation:

  • The Pearl Index is an indicator of Couple protection practices in the community. Defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 women years of exposure. It is the percentage of eligible couples protected against childbirth by family planning.

It is a standard method to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptive methods in preventing unintended pregnancies.

Contraceptive Method

Indication

Pearl Index (Failure Rate per 100 Woman-Years)

Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Women with irregular menstrual cycles or acne seeking contraception

0.3 - 9

Intrauterine Device (IUD)

Long-term contraception; contraindications to estrogen

0.1 - 0.8 (Copper)

0.1 - 0.2 (Hormonal)

Condoms (Male)

Prevention of STIs and contraception

2 - 18

Condoms (Female)

Non-hormonal, barrier method

5 - 21

Contraceptive Implant
  • Long-term contraception; high efficacy, minimal user intervention
  • Considered in women with seizures or sickle cell disorder

0.05 - 0.3

Contraceptive Injection (e.g., Depo-Provera)

Long-term, non-daily hormonal contraception; those who cannot use estrogen

0.2 - 6

Vaginal Ring (e.g., NuvaRing)

Monthly regimen with local hormone delivery

0.3 - 9

Sterilization (Female Tubal Ligation)

Permanent contraception

0.5 - 0.1

Sterilization (Vasectomy)

Permanent contraception; more effective than female sterilization

0.1 - 0.15

Natural Family Planning

Natural method, often for religious or personal reasons

2 - 25

Emergency Contraception Pills

Post-coital contraception

1 - 2

Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM)

Breastfeeding women, within first 6 months postpartum with exclusive breastfeeding and amenorrhea

0.5 - 2

questions.text: How is the contraceptive shown in the below image inserted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hysteroscopic

Explanation:

  • The contraceptive device depicted in the image is the Essure coil, a permanent sterilization method. It is inserted hysteroscopically, which involves the use of a hysteroscope through the vagina into the uterus. The device is then placed into each fallopian tube to create a physical barrier, causing fibrosis and occlusion of the tubes over time.

Essure

  • It is a permanent, non-surgical form of sterilization that involves placing small coils into the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy.

Procedure: The procedure involves the insertion of small, flexible coils (made of stainless steel and polyester fibers) into the fallopian tubes through the cervix and uterus. This is done under local anesthesia.

Mechanism: Over a few months, the body forms scar tissue around the coils, which blocks the fallopian tubes, preventing sperm from reaching the eggs.

Indications:

  • Permanent contraception for women who are sure they do not want future pregnancies.
  • Suitable for women who are not planning to undergo traditional tubal ligation or who have contraindications for surgery.

Advantages:

  • Non-surgical
  • Quick recovery: Most women can resume normal activities within a day or two.
  • Performed under local anesthesia.
  • Permanent

Effectiveness: After about three months, a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed to confirm tube blockage.

Complications:

  • Side effects: Mild cramping, bleeding, or infection after the procedure.
  • Rare complications: Expulsion or migration of the coils, perforation of the uterus or fallopian tubes.

questions.text: In an asymptomatic woman aged 35 years, an ultrasound scan reveals a single-chamber cyst measuring 6 cm in the ovary. Serology results are negative. The recommended approach for this condition includes treatment measures such as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs

Explanation:

  • The correct approach for a functional ovarian cyst that is asymptomatic, unilocular, less than 7 cm, and with negative serology, is conservative management. Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) helps suppress ovarian function and promotes cyst resolution. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously without the need for surgical intervention.

Incorrect Options:

Laparotomy (Option A) is not indicated for a simple 6 cm functional cyst. It is reserved for larger cysts (>7 cm), persistent cysts, or those with suspicious features.

Ovariotomy (Option C) involves the removal of the ovary and is not necessary for functional cysts. It is reserved for cases of ovarian torsion, malignancy, or complicated cysts.

CA-125 testing (Option D) is used to monitor ovarian cancer or evaluate complex adnexal masses. It is not applicable for a benign, functional ovarian cyst in an asymptomatic patient.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below does not represent an absolute contraindication for the use of the device depicted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HIV-infected women

Explanation:

  • The device depicted is the CuT 380A intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD).
  • The use of IUDs is not contraindicated in women with HIV infection.
  • In fact, IUDs, including the CuT 380A, are considered safe and effective for most women, including those who are HIV-positive, as long as there are no other contraindications.
  • The device works by preventing fertilization, offering long-term contraception.

Contraindications of IUCD:

Absolute Contraindications

Relative Contraindications
  • Pregnancy (Option B)
  • Current Pelvic Infection (Option D)
  • Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding (Option A)
  • Active Cervical or Uterine Cancer
  • Distorted Uterine Cavity
  • History of Ectopic Pregnancy
  • Immunocompromised States
  • History of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • Severe Menstrual Pain or Heavy Periods
  • Postpartum Women
  • Trophoblastic disease
  • Previous Intrauterine Device (IUD) Expulsion

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes for emergency contraception within 8 hours after engaging in sexual intercourse. She expresses a preference for a single pill rather than multiple pills. What would be your recommendation in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

Explanation:

  • Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the most appropriate option for emergency contraception in this case. It is a progestin-only pill and is highly effective when taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. Since the patient prefers a single-pill regimen, this option is ideal. It does not contain estrogen, avoiding estrogen-related side effects such as nausea or vomiting.

Emergency Contraceptive Methods

Method

Time Period for Use

Oral Contraceptive Pills

Levonorgestrel

1.5 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Combination Pills (Yuzpe Regimen)

Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl estradiol

Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg + Ethinyl estradiol 0.1 mg per tablet

2 doses, 12 hours apart

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Levonorgestrel

Levonorgestrel

0.75 mg per tablet (take 2 tablets)

1 dose

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Ulipristal Acetate

Ulipristal acetate

30 mg (single dose)

1 dose

Within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex

Copper IUD (Best)

Copper IUD

N/A (inserted by healthcare provider)

Within 5 days after unprotected sex

Mifepristone (Less Common)

Mifepristone (in combination with misoprostol)

200 mg (single dose)

Within 72 hours after unprotected sex

Incorrect Options:

While levonorgestrel 0.75 mg (Option A) is used in some regimens, it requires two doses (one pill initially and another 12 hours later). Since the patient prefers a single pill, this option is not suitable.

Ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel (Option B) combination contains both estrogen (ethinyl estradiol) and progestin (levonorgestrel). While effective, the estrogen component increases the risk of side effects, including nausea and vomiting, which the patient is trying to avoid.

Desogestrel 3 mg (Option D) is a progestin-only contraceptive, but it is not typically used for emergency contraception. Furthermore, it is often combined with estrogen, which would introduce unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below.

choices.text: For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) For tubal ligation

Explanation:

The Falope ring involves using a specialized applicator to place a Silastic ring around the midisthmic portion of the tube, leading to ischemic necrosis over time. Care must be taken to avoid laceration of the tube during application. The Hulka and Filshie clips are applied across the mid-isthmus of the tube. Proper placement of the clips is crucial to ensure complete occlusion of the tube.

The falope ring applicator is not used for ligation of the uterine artery during hysterectomy (Option B). Hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus and may or may not involve ligation of the uterine arteries, but the falope ring applicator is not used for this purpose.

An ovarian cystectomy (Option C) is a surgical procedure to remove ovarian cysts while preserving healthy ovarian tissue. The falope ring applicator is not used for ovarian cystectomy, as it is unrelated to this procedure.

An ectopic pregnancy (Option D) occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, usually in the fallopian tube. The treatment for ectopic pregnancy typically involves surgical intervention, but the falope ring applicator is not used for this purpose.

questions.text: A lady on OCPs presents with white discharge per vagina with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow and shows normal lactobacilli with an acidic pH on examination of the discharge. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Increased normal vaginal discharge

  • The lady is experiencing an odourless and white discharge, without itching or redness, with normal flora leading to the diagnosis of a physiological increase of normal vaginal discharge, which is a minor complication associated with OCP usage.

Complications associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Complication

Details

Minor Complications

Nausea, Vomiting, Headache

Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolve over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent.

Mastalgia

Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles.

Weight Gain

Minimal long-term weight gain

Menstrual Abnormalities

Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use.

Libido

Changes in sexual desire can occur

Leukorrhea

Increase in vaginal discharge

Major Complications

Depression

Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations

Hypertension

Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment.

Vascular Complications
  • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking.
  • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction

Cholestatic Jaundice

Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs.

Neoplasia

Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

Candidiasis (Option A), commonly known as a yeast infection, can cause a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. It is often associated with itching, redness, and swelling of the vulva. The pH level is typically normal or slightly acidic.

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Option C) is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and often presents with a thin, milky-white vaginal discharge that can sometimes appear greyish or yellowish. BV is not usually associated with itching, redness, or pain, and the pH level of the vagina is often elevated but can have a characteristic fishy order, especially after intercourse.

Trichomoniasis (Option D) is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause a frothy, greenish-yellow, foul-smelling discharge. It is often associated with itching, redness, and discomfort. The pH level is usually elevated.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Female condom

Explanation:

  • Female condom: Female condoms are soft, loose-fitting pouches with flexible rings at each end. One ring is inserted into the vagina to hold the condom in place, while the other ring remains outside to cover the area around the vaginal opening.

Images of various barrier methods:

 

 

 


Incorrect Options:

Male condoms (Option A) are typically made of latex or polyurethane and are worn over the erect penis to prevent pregnancy and protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). However, the image described does not depict a male condom.

A diaphragm (Option C) is a barrier contraceptive device that is inserted into the vagina to cover the cervix and prevent sperm from entering the uterus. It is usually made of latex or silicone and requires fitting by a healthcare provider. The image and description do not match a diaphragm.

Similar to a diaphragm, a cervical cap (Option D) is a barrier contraceptive device that is placed over the cervix to prevent sperm from entering the uterus. It is smaller in size compared to a diaphragm and fits directly onto the cervix. The image and description do not correspond to a cervical cap.

questions.text: In what procedure is the instrument shown in the image utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tubectomy (Female Sterilization)

Explanation:

There are five primary methods of female sterilization:

  1. Tubal sterilization during laparotomy for cesarean delivery or other abdominal surgeries.
  2. Postpartum mini-laparotomy immediately after vaginal delivery.
  3. Interval minilaparotomy.
  4. Laparoscopy.
  5. Hysteroscopy.

Surgical Technique

  • The Pomeroy technique, or a modified version of it, is typically chosen for tubal sterilization during laparotomy. In the classic Pomeroy method, a loop of the fallopian tube is excised, and the base of the loop is ligated with a single absorbable suture.
  • The Madlener technique, which is no longer used due to high failure rates, involved crushing a loop of the tube, ligating it with a permanent suture, and excising the segment.
  • Failure rates for the Pomeroy and partial salpingectomy procedures are low
  • In contrast, pregnancy after sterilization using the Irving or Uchida methods is exceedingly rare. The Irving method involves excising the midsection of the tube, and then turning back the proximal stump and suturing it into a small stab wound in the uterine wall, forming a blind loop.
  • The Uchida method involves injecting a saline–epinephrine solution beneath the mucosa of the tube, separating the mucosa from the underlying tissue. The mucosa is then incised, and a segment of the tube is excised. The mucosa is sutured closed, burying the proximal stump and separating it from the distal end.

Laparoscopy

  • Laparoscopy is the most commonly used method for interval sterilization. During the procedure, the abdomen is inflated with gas, and a laparoscope is inserted through a trocar at the lower edge of the umbilicus. Although single-puncture laparoscopic sterilization can be done using an operating laparoscope, a second, and sometimes third, trocar is often inserted in the lower quadrants or suprapubic area to facilitate the use of special grasping forceps. Laparoscopic sterilization is typically performed in a hospital under general anesthesia, though local anesthesia with conscious sedation can also be used. Most patients do not require overnight hospitalization after the procedure.

 

Incorrect Options:

A punch biopsy (Option A) is a procedure to obtain a small sample of tissue for examination. The instrument used in a punch biopsy is typically a circular blade or punch, which is different from the instrument depicted.

A bone marrow biopsy set (Option C) is used to obtain a sample of bone marrow for diagnostic purposes. It typically includes a needle and a syringe, and the instrument depicted does not resemble the components of a bone marrow biopsy set.

The instrument depicted does not resemble a trocar and cannula used in laparoscopy (Option D), which typically consists of a sharp-pointed instrument and a hollow tube for accessing the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is not involved in the action of oral contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increase GnRH release

Explanation:

Oral contraceptives, particularly combination hormonal contraceptives (CHCs), work through the following mechanisms:

  • Inhibition of Ovulation (Option C): The estrogen and progestin components suppress gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion from the hypothalamus. This leads to reduced release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) by the pituitary, preventing ovulation.
  • Thickening of Cervical Mucus (Option B): Progestin increases the viscosity of cervical mucus, creating a barrier that impedes sperm entry into the uterus.
  • Endometrial Alteration: Hormonal changes modify the uterine lining, making it unsuitable for implantation (Option A).

An increase in GnRH release would stimulate the pituitary to produce FSH and LH, promoting ovulation rather than suppressing it. Since this contradicts the mechanism of action of oral contraceptives, Option D is correct as it does not align with their effects.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who is on oral contraceptive pills for contraception has forgotten to take her pills on 4 different days in the last 2 weeks. She presents to the primary health centre, asking for advice. What would you suggest to her?

choices.text: Take 4 pills now, continue the schedule, and use a barrier method of contraception
Take 1 pill now, continue the schedule, and use a barrier method of contraception
Take 1 pill now, use a barrier method, and consider emergency contraception in case of recent intercourse
Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception.

Explanation: Discard the pack, start a new one immediately, and use an alternate method of contraception (e.g., barrier method) for the next 7 days, as missing 4 pills disrupts the contraceptive efficacy.

Missed oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Number of Pills Missed

Timing of Missed Pills

Management

Additional Considerations

1 Pill

Anytime
  • Take the missed pill as soon as remembered and continue the rest at the usual time ( Take two pills in one day).

No additional contraception is needed. Emergency contraception (EC) is not required.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 1 or Week 2
  • Take the most recent missed pill as soon as remembered ( Take two pills in one day) and continue the rest as usual.
  • Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for 7 days.

Consider EC if missed during Week 1 and unprotected sex occurred in the previous 5 days.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 3 or Week 4
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

3 or More Consecutive Pills

Anytime
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

Explanation: Laparoscopic Sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception.

Laparoscopic Sterilization:

  • An irreversible method of tubal sterilization involving laparoscopic access to the fallopian tubes, resulting in permanent contraception.
  • Procedure:
    • Performed under local or general anesthesia.
    • A small subumbilical incision is made, and CO₂ is used for pneumoperitoneum.
    • A trocar and cannula are inserted, and the operating laparoscope provides visualization.
    • The fallopian tubes are clipped, banded, or cauterized using a Filshie clip, Hulka clip, or silastic ring.
    • The procedure is completed with a subcuticular skin stitch.
  • Failure Rate: Between 0.2% and 1.5%, depending on the technique used.
  • Advantages:
    • Small, nearly invisible subumbilical scar.
    • Can be performed under local anesthesia as an outpatient.
    • Highly reversible, with a success rate of over 70%, although considered irreversible after the procedure.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Expensive equipment and maintenance.
    • Requires skilled personnel.
    • Mortality (1-2 per 100,000).
  • Complications:
    • Rare but serious, including abdominal wall emphysema, bleeding, uterine perforation, and incorrect ring placement.
    • Ectopic pregnancy (0.2%-0.3%) and hydrosalpinx may occur.
  • Contraindications:
    • Cardiac or pulmonary disease
    • Previous abdominal surgery
    • Extreme obesity
    • PID

Copper T (Option A) is a long-acting reversible contraceptive method, an intrauterine device (IUD). It is effective for up to 10 years and is reversible as it can be removed at any time, and fertility generally returns quickly after removal.

Implanon (Option B) is a subdermal implant that provides contraception for up to 3 years. It is a reversible method, as fertility typically returns within 1 month of removal.

Combined oral contraceptive pills (Option D) contain a mixture of estrogen (ethinylestradiol) and progestogen. They are a reversible method of contraception, with 90% of women returning to normal ovulatory cycles within 3 months after discontinuing the pills.

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptives is used in India?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

 

Explanation: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is an emergency contraception used in India.

 

Emergency Contraceptives (EC):

  • Prevents unintended pregnancy after unprotected or inadequately protected intercourse.
  • It includes both emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) and the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD):
  1. Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs):
  • Levonorgestrel (LNG):
    • Available as a single 1.5 mg pill.
    • Most effective within 72 hours but can be used up to 120 hours.
    • Commonly available in India.
  • Ulipristal Acetate (UPA): (Option C)
    • Single-dose pill containing 30 mg of ulipristal acetate.
    • Effective for up to 120 hours (5 days) post-intercourse.
    • Approved by US-FDA and European medicine agencies.
    • Not available in India.
  • Combined Hormonal Regimens (Yuzpe Method):
    • Involves taking 2 doses, 12 hours apart.
    • Each dose contains at least 100 micrograms of ethinyl estradiol and 500 micrograms of levonorgestrel.
  1. Intrauterine Device (IUD):
  • Copper IUD:
    • Most effective form of EC.
    • It can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Misoprostol 400 mcg (Option A): Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, is commonly used in combination with mifepristone for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). It induces uterine contractions to facilitate abortion and is not classified as an emergency contraceptive.


Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg (Option B): High-dose ethinyl estradiol (EE) combined with levonorgestrel is used in the Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception; EE alone at this dose does not function as an emergency contraceptive.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding vasectomy?

choices.text: The procedure is done under local anaesthesia
Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure
A no-scalpel technique is being widely used now
The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure

Explanation:

Sterility post-vasectomy is achieved by 3 months (12 weeks), not 3 weeks.

Vasectomy is a safe, minimally invasive, and highly effective method of male sterilization.

  • The procedure is performed under local anesthesia to minimize discomfort. (Option A ruled out)
  • The no-scalpel technique, which involves a small puncture instead of a traditional incision, is now widely used and associated with fewer complications. (Option C ruled out)
  • The vas deferens, the tube responsible for transporting sperm, is divided during the procedure. (Option D ruled out)
  • Sperm present in the post-distal ligation area can lead to pregnancy, hence contraception is required for 3 months or 20 ejaculations, whichever is later.
  • Sterilization is confirmed by semen analysis, with at least 2 analyses showing azoospermia.
  • Studies show that 80% of men are sterile after 15 ejaculations or about 6 weeks, and 89% are sperm-free by 10 weeks. The remaining sperm is gradually cleared, making the safe time period approximately 3 months.

questions.text: All are long-term reversible methods of contraception, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

Female sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception. It involves surgical procedures like tubal ligation, where the fallopian tubes are either severed, destroyed, or blocked, preventing the eggs from reaching the uterus. This method is permanent and cannot be reversed, making it distinct from other long-term reversible methods.

 

Progestin injections (Option A), like NET-EN, are a form of reversible contraception. These injections prevent pregnancy for a few months and are easily reversible once discontinued.

 

Progestin implants (e.g., Nexplanon) (Option B) are small rods placed under the skin that release a hormone to prevent pregnancy. They are highly effective, reversible, and can last for several years.


Both levonorgestrel-releasing (e.g., Mirena) (Option D) and copper-containing (e.g., CuT-380A) intrauterine devices (IUDs) are long-term, reversible contraceptive methods. They can remain in place for several years and are removed if pregnancy is desired.

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except:

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Reduction in the risk of ectopic pregnancy
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV

 

Explanation:

Oral contraceptives (OCPs) provide numerous non-contraceptive benefits. However, they do not prevent sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV. Barrier methods, such as condoms, are necessary for protection against STDs.

 

Mechanism of Action of OCPs

 

Combined Oral Contraceptives (COCPs): Contain ethinylestradiol and progestins.

  • Suppress ovulation: Inhibit FSH and LH release from the pituitary.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: Progesterone prevents sperm penetration.

 

Progestin-Only Pills (Mini-pills): Act primarily by altering cervical mucus and endometrial environment.

 

Hormonal Content

Primary Mechanism

Secondary Effects

Estrogen

Suppresses FSH

Stabilizes endometrium, reduces bleeding

Progestin

Suppresses LH

Thickens cervical mucus, thins endometrium


 

Non-Contraceptive Benefits of OCPs

 

Reduction in ovarian cancer risk (Option A)

Suppresses ovulation, reducing exposure to gonadotropins that may induce ovarian epithelial damage.

Reduction in endometrial cancer risk (Option B)

Progestin opposes estrogen's proliferative effects on the endometrium.

Reduction in ectopic pregnancy (Option D)

Suppresses ovulation and reduces pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Management of PCOD

Regularizes menstrual cycles and reduces androgen levels.

Improvement in acne

Reduces androgen levels, decreasing sebaceous gland activity.

Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea

Reduces endometrial proliferation and menstrual blood loss.

questions.text: Which of the following can not be used for emergency contraception?

choices.text: LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

Explanation:

  • LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours is not to be used for emergency contraception.

Emergency Contraceptives (EC):

  • Prevents unintended pregnancy after unprotected or inadequately protected intercourse.
  • It includes both emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) and the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD):
  • Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs):
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG): (Option A)
      • Available as a single 1.5 mg pill.
      • Most effective within 72 hours but can be used up to 120 hours.
      • Commonly available in India.
    • Ulipristal Acetate (UPA):
      • Single-dose pill containing 30 mg of ulipristal acetate. (Option D)
      • Effective for up to 120 hours (5 days) post-intercourse.
      • Approved by US-FDA and European medicine agencies.
      • Not available in India.
    • Combined Hormonal Regimens (Yuzpe Method):
      • Involves taking 2 doses, 12 hours apart.
      • Each dose contains at least 100 micrograms of ethinyl estradiol and 500 micrograms of levonorgestrel.
    • Centchroman:
      • Two 60 mg tablets, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours. (Option B)
      • Effective only if taken within 24 hours post-intercourse.
      • Requires adequate trials to establish its effectiveness as emergency contraception.
  • Intrauterine Device (IUD):
    • Copper IUD:
      • Most effective form of EC.
      • It can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: What is the dose of Misoprostol in medical abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 800 micrograms

Explanation:

  • The standard and widely accepted dose of misoprostol for medical abortion (up to 10 weeks gestation) is 800 micrograms.

Medical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Regimen

Indication

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Medical abortion; Miscarriage.

Best method with a high success rate.

 

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Used when Mifepristone is not available.

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

MTP

Less commonly used.

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline.

MTP

Longer induction duration is rarely used.
  • Complications: Bleeding, Cramping, incomplete abortion.
  • Rh D-negative women should receive anti-D immunoglobulin to prevent Rh alloimmunization.
  • Counselling and provision of post-abortion contraception are essential, as ovulation can occur as early as eight days after an abortion.

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • Suction evacuation for medical termination of pregnancy can typically be performed up to 12 weeks of gestation.

Methods of Termination of Pregnancy:

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks (Option B & C)

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks (Option D)
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

 

Medical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Regimen

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Best method with a high success rate.

 

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Used when Mifepristone is not available.

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

Less commonly used.

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline.

Longer induction duration is rarely used.

 

Surgical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around - 610 mmHg.

 

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

 
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

Karman’s cannula

 

Hegar’s dilator

 

Uterine curette

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)

  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

Ovum forceps

Hysterotomy

  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.
